posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
So I’m trying to get path following to work with our old 2022 robot. I have followed the path following wpilib example.

Unfortunately, when I run it on the robot, the robot just shakes uncontrollably.

here’s my code: drive subsystem:

robotcontainer:

constants:

this is my SYSID configuration: Screenshot 2022-12-01 170053 2256×1503 526 KB

Screenshot 2022-12-01 170053 2256×1503 526 KB

Screenshot 2022-12-01 170053 2256×1503 526 KB

I’m not sure what I’m doing wrong. Is my SYSID configuration correct. We’re using the NEO integrated encoders. If anyone has come across this issue can let me know how to fix it that would be great!!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Make sure you enter a realistic measurement delay into SysId.  The internal NEO encoders have a substantial filter on their measured velocity.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: What do you mean by measurement delay?

posts.name: Matteo H Kimura
posts.cooked: In the feedback analysis there are different gain presets. In order to accurately configure the P value, the system needs to be aware of the measurement delay of the encoder (see feedback analysis there’s Measurement Delay at the bottom). I believe there is a Spark Max Brushless Preset that gets the NEO encoder delay for you.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: Do I need to add anything in my code to account for this or is it just SYSid?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: SysId will adjust the reported feedback gain for you.  Just use the gains it recommends once you have specified the correct measurement delay.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
So, I’ve implemented that solution. Sadly, it still shakes uncontrollably. It sort of looks like it is following the path though. Is it possible my conversion factors are incorrect?

this is how I implement them in my drive subsystem:

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
Gandagorn:

You probably want all three 1 ’s to be be 1.0 .  Java’s integer division may not be doing what you expect.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: So it’s following the path now but it is going way too far than it should. I have it set to go 2 meters and It goes 6 meters. The motors are in brake mode. Are my conversions wrong?
Yep. The equation for the circumference of a wheel is 2 pi radius not 2 pi diameter. Change to pi * diameter.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: Oh goodness. I can’t believe I missed that! Thanks so much!

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: I finally got it working! I wanted to thank everyone so much for the help!
